patterns: tell me definition meaning of physic
responses: Are you sure you want to know about PHYSIC??? Then ask me about 'constant in physic'!!!
Physics is the natural science of matter, involving the study of matter, its fundamental constituents, its motion and behavior through space and time, and the related entities of energy and force.
Physics is one of the most fundamental scientific disciplines, with its main goal being to understand how the universe behaves.
Physics is one of the oldest academic disciplines and, through its inclusion of astronomy, perhaps the oldest.

patterns: tell me about a constant in physic
tell me about a term in physic
tell me about an intesting thing in physic
responses: a stands for Acceleration, the rate of change of the velocity of an object with respect to time.
A stands for The amplitude of a periodic variable, a measure of its change in a single period (such as time or spatial period).
B stands for The magnetic flux density, amount of magnetic flux through unit area taken perpendicular to direction of magnetic flux.
c stands for Speed of Light, a universal physical constant that is exactly equal to 299,792,458 metres per second
C stands for Capacitance, the capability of a material object or device to store electric charge.
d stands for Distance, a numerical or occasionally qualitative measurement of how far apart objects or points are.
D stands for Electric induction, a vector field that appears in Maxwell's equations.
e stands for Elementary Charge, the electric charge carried by a single proton or, equivalently, the magnitude of the negative electric charge carried by a single electron, which has charge -1 e.
E stands for Energy, the quantitative property that is transferred to a body or to a physical system, recognizable in the performance of work and in the form of heat and light.
f stands for Frequency, the number of occurrences of a repeating event per unit of time.
F stands for The Faraday constant, is the electric charge per mole of elementary charges.
F stands for Force, an influence that causes the motion of an object with mass to change its velocity.
g stands for The standard acceleration due to gravity, the nominal gravitational acceleration of an object in a vacuum near the surface of the Earth.

G stands for Gravitational Constant, an empirical physical constant involved in the calculation of gravitational effects in Sir Isaac Newton's law of universal gravitation and in Albert Einstein's theory of general relativity.
h stands for The Planck constant, a fundamental physical constant of foundational importance in quantum mechanics.
H stands for Magnetic field strength, a measure of the intensity of a magnetic field in a given area of that field.
I stands for Electric current, a flow of charged particles, such as electrons or ions, moving through an electrical conductor or space.
J stands for Impulse, the integral of a force, F, over the time interval, t, for which it acts.
K stands for Kinetic energy of an object, the form of energy that it possesses due to its motion.
L stands for Inductance, the tendency of an electrical conductor to oppose a change in the electric current flowing through it.
m stands for Mass, an intrinsic property of a body.
p stands for Momentum, the product of the mass and velocity of an object.
P stands for Power, the amount of energy transferred or converted per unit time.
q stands for Electric charge, the physical property of matter that causes it to experience a force when placed in an electromagnetic field.
R stands for Electrical resistance of an object is a measure of its opposition to the flow of electric current.
S stands for Entropy, a scientific concept, as well as a measurable physical property, that is most commonly associated with a state of disorder, randomness, or uncertainty.
t stands for Time, the continued sequence of existence and events that occurs in an apparently irreversible succession from the past, through the present, into the future.
T stands for Period, the time taken to complete one cycle of an oscillation or rotation.
T stands for Temperature, a physical quantity that expresses quantitatively the perceptions of hotness and coldness.
U stands for Voltage, the difference in electric potential between two points.
U stands for Potential energy is the energy held by an object because of its position relative to other objects, stresses within itself, its electric charge, or other factors.
v stands for Velocity, the speed and the direction of motion of an object.
V stands for The electric potential, defined as the amount of work energy needed per unit of electric charge to move this charge from a reference point to the specific point in an electric field.

What season do you like best
responses: Spring, also known as springtime, is one of the four temperate seasons, succeeding winter and preceding summer.
Summer is the hottest of the four temperate seasons, occurring after spring and before autumn.
Autumn, also known as fall in American English and Canadian English, is one of the four temperate seasons on Earth.
Winter is the coldest season of the year in polar and temperate climates. It occurs after autumn and before spring.
